item.title: Washed-Up Pro Gamer Goes Viral For Griefing In Arc Raiders: â€˜You Want Optional PvP Go Play WoWâ€˜
item.content:encoded:
The PvP nature of multiplayer extraction shooter Arc Raiders has been contentious since the gameâ€™s launch. There are many who see the ability to kill and be killed by other players are vital for the gameâ€™s tension and enjoyment. There are others who argue itâ€™s antithetical to the conventions of a game in which a scant, brave few are trying to bring back resources to those living underground. Either way, Arc Raiders players have reached a fascinating and fragile understanding in which most people, most of the time, donâ€™t kill. So when a retired pro gamer shows up and just starts slaughtering everything, itâ€™sâ€¦well, itâ€™s just rude!

As IGN reports, Taylor â€œTHumpâ€ Humphriesâ€”a former pro at games like Apex Legends, Rocket Arena, and H1Z1â€”has decided to spend his spare time taking out as many â€œcasualâ€ players as he can in Embarkâ€™s breakout hit game. On recent Twitch streams, THump has been broadcasting himself griefing in Arc Raiders for, seemingly, his lone amusement. His most recent stream, a grueling 13 hours long, is primarily the guy killing other players in a game in which most people opt to be peaceful.

Now, let me stress, heâ€™s doing nothing wrong. Arc Raiders has PvP for a really good reason: it makes it a thousand times more tense to play. Were it only PvE (and honestly, all the wrong parts of me dearly wishes it were), then every interaction with another player would become banal, lacking the terrifying hope for uneasy, fleeting alliances that make it so exciting. Every time a player deliberately kills you, it feels like wanton betrayal, though itâ€™s clearly well within the rules.

The issue with THumpâ€™s murderstreams is that the entire exercise is the video game equivalent of shitposting. His commentary is incessant irony, with him laughing as he makes other people sad. And, I dunno, Iâ€™m too old and tired to find that shit funny. Somehow this is proving entertaining enough to the streamer that heâ€™s doing it night after night of late, most recently delighting in lobbing grenades.

A few days back, it was this post on X that really riled people up, as THump dropped a clip of his killing a party of four at the very start of a run, when they didnâ€™t even have any loot to steal. â€œWe just started, I have nothing,â€ said the first person he killed. â€œWhat scum man,â€ they added after the second kill.

â€” THUMP (@THump) December 18, 2025

Given THumpâ€™s a troll, his responses to those objectingâ€”such as â€œI come from a place where PvP is not optionalâ€¦itâ€™s a way of life. You want optional PvP go play WoWâ€œâ€”are obviously insincere. When one person calls him â€œanother toxic streamer,â€ and suggests heâ€™d have a better time helping other players rather than killing them, he replies, â€œId rather ruin others time than have fun myself.â€

But, again, heâ€™s not doing anything wrong. While THumpâ€™s repeated claims of innocence, that heâ€™s just killing other players â€œin a PvP game,â€ are clearly disingenuous, thereâ€™s no arguing that Arc Raiders isnâ€™t designed to facilitate it. Honestly, as much as seeing someone do this for clout is embarrassing to watch, I take huge solace in knowing that his actions are something that stands out among players. I really rather love that this ostensibly PvP game has somehow engendered a player base that, 90 percent of the time, opts not to kill, even when thereâ€™s personal gain in doing so. In 2025, that feels like a beacon of hope, and a douche like THump exploiting it only highlights how valuable it is.
